title: AB 1837
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability is established as the statewide postsecondary education coordination and planning agency within the Governor's office, under the direct control of an executive director. The Governor appoints the Executive Director of the Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability, who has all duties and powers vested by law, including hiring staff and contracting for services. The appointment is subject to Senate confirmation, and the salary is determined by the Government Code. An advisory board is established to review and make recommendations on the functions of the Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability. It consists of members with experience in postsecondary education appointed by the Senate Committee on Rules and the Speaker of the Assembly. The office must consult with the advisory board on its operations and recommendations. The advisory board, governed by the Bagley-Keene Open Meeting Act, meets quarterly to discuss higher education in California. They appoint a member to communicate with the Legislature, develop an annual report on higher education, review the Executive Director's performance, and receive reimbursement for expenses. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability advises the Governor, Legislature, and other officials on postsecondary education. It consults with higher education segments and stakeholders, including faculty, students, K-12 representatives, and the business community. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability advises on state goals, priorities, and performance in higher education. It reviews cross-segmental initiatives, advises on new institutions, and informs the Legislature and Governor. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability reviews proposals for new programs and coordinates with nearby educational institutions. It acts as a clearinghouse for postsecondary education information and maintains a comprehensive database for longitudinal studies of students. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability maintains a database for educational research purposes, ensuring compatibility with various educational systems and providing internet access to higher education segments while complying with student privacy laws. The office requires authorization from postsecondary educational institutions before sharing personally identifiable student information for regulatory purposes. Additionally, the office must notify relevant committees and officials before making significant changes to student information in the database. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability reviews proposals for changes in eligibility pools for admission to public institutions and postsecondary education, conducts studies on high school graduates' eligibility for UC and CSU, submits reports to the Legislature, manages data systems, and maintains expertise in programmatic, policy, and fiscal matters. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability may require data from public postsecondary institutions on various aspects for effective planning and policy development. They report to the Governor and Legislature annually on their progress. The Legislative Analyst's Office reviews their performance and reports to the Legislature by January 1, 2020. The article will be in effect until January 1, 2021, and may be repealed unless extended by a later statute. If costs are mandated by the state, reimbursement will be made to local agencies and school districts. The Legislature intends to create the Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability for postsecondary education coordination and planning.
